data.title: Francis goes to Hollywood: The creator of House Of Cards schemer Francis Urquhart reveals how Kevin Spaceyâ€™s bringing him back to life
data.meta_description: Iâ€™d never written a book before but with those words of encouragement ringing in my ears, I found a quiet seat beside the swimming pool, and with only an umbrella and a bottle of wine for company, began scratching away.
data.text:
It all started as a bit of a joke. I was reading a novel on holiday and hating it. I whined and moaned over lunch, perhaps too loudly, so it was suggested to me that if I could do any better perhaps I should get on with it, and stop being â€˜so bloody pompousâ€™.

Fair enough. Iâ€™d never written a book before but with those words of encouragement ringing in my ears, I found a quiet seat beside the swimming pool, and with only an umbrella and a bottle of wine for company, began scratching away.

It was 1987. Iâ€™d just come out of a bruising election campaign working as Chief Of Staff for Maggie Thatcher.

Ian Richardson (with Susannah Harker) as the original Urquhart

The handbag had swung very firmly in my direction, most unfairly I thought, and I was sore and angry, so the book was bound to be about the dark arts of politics.

I dreamed up a character, named him after his initials â€“ FU â€“ and so the supremely Machiavellian figure of Tory Chief Whip Francis Urquhart was born. I didnâ€™t know it, but my life was about to change forever.

The book was called House Of Cards and it became an immediate bestseller, poking all sorts of wicked fun at the British Establishment â€“ John Major was kind enough to say it had done for his job what Dracula had done for babysitting.

Then the BBC took it up and turned it into one of the all-time classic television series, starring Ian Richardson, that wonderful actor whose gaze could freeze a man solid at 20 paces. And almost by accident I became a full-time author.

The opening words of the series, adapted for television by Andrew Davies, still ring in my ears. â€˜Nothing lasts forever,â€™ FU says in a voice that sounds like the opening of a coffin lid, and so it proved. Andrew and I had a great falling-out, handbags-at-dawn stuff, and after three hugely successful books and TV series we killed the character off and went our separate ways.

That was 17 years ago, and yet dear old FU has never allowed me to forget him, for next month the cameras, the lights, the sound gear, carpenters, caterers and general chaos of a huge television crew will be gathering in Baltimore, Maryland, just a handful of miles up Interstate 95 from the White House, as the role is revived by another brilliant actor, Kevin Spacey.

The American Establishment is about to be turned on its head. FU lives! But now heâ€™s Francis Underwood â€“ Urquhart was just too British Isles. The project is staggering. Twenty-six hours of television have been commissioned, and thatâ€™s just the start.

FU has transformed my life. He picked me up, battered and miserable beside a swimming pool a quarter of a century ago...

The announcement that filming would start in Maryland was made by the stateâ€™s governor. It will be directed by David Fincher of Golden Globe and Academy Award fame, whose latest film The Girl With The Dragon Tattoo is filling cinemas around the world. The lead actress is the gorgeous Robin Wright, who plays FUâ€™s wife, an even more manipulative creature than in the original. The budget for all this is a staggering $100 million.

And itâ€™s Spacey, the man who is Lex Luthor and Richard III all rolled into one and among the most gifted actors on the planet. As I write this I find I am shaking. It was only meant to be a jokeâ€¦ Iâ€™m one of the executive producers. Iâ€™m also now in the House of Lords, supposed to be respectable, a responsible type â€“ yet my baby is about to come back from the dead and haunt the corridors of power in the worldâ€™s mightiest capital city.

Thereâ€™s no guarantee of success, of course. Plenty of other British successes have tried to cross the Atlantic and drowned far off the coast. Not even sparkling ideas like the BBCâ€™s 2003 thriller State Of Play, with a stellar Hollywood cast, was as well received in the US as it was here.

But I have no doubt this will translate very powerfully. There are some traits that are common to all political systems â€“ ambition, lust, and perhaps most of all wickedness. The new House Of Cards will have all three in abundance. And every great project needs a bit of luck.

Michael had just come out of a bruising election campaign working as Chief Of Staff for Maggie Thatcher before he wrote his first book

Timing is everything, and with enormous cheek (and extraordinary good fortune) the first episode of the BBCâ€™s House Of Cards went out in the week that Margaret Thatcher was forced to resign. We were all glued to our TV sets as the drama unfolded. The nation saw the tears as she left Downing Street, then we watched FU smiling like the Grim Reaper in the background. The edges of reality grew blurred.

John Major, deep into the fight to succeed the fallen Maggie, told me his campaign headquarters ground to a halt every Sunday evening as his staff watched the next episode. Drama had taken over from the real world. Everyone wanted to find out what was going to happen next. And the new version will be ready to air alongside the US presidential election.

Dare we try to pull the same trick twice? Iâ€™m not allowed to say, but since the foibles of politicians are not only endless but also irresistibly entertaining, itâ€™s conceivable the series will still be running through the next presidential election, too.

The West Wing ran for almost seven years, and FU has never been less than deadly ambitious. And the US producers have taken up the rights to all three of my original books. They want this to run and run, all round the world. FU will be back on our screens in Britain, too. The names, accents and backdrops will change and expand, but he will still be totally recognisable as the modern Machiavelli.

FU has transformed my life. He picked me up, battered and miserable beside a swimming pool a quarter of a century ago and has provided for me and my family ever since. He has also brought tears to my eyes. At Ian Richardsonâ€™s memorial service in the Actorsâ€™ Church in Covent Garden, we had just finished saying goodbye to him when the speakers crackled and his voice came over the sound system. Those haunting words â€“

â€˜Nothing lasts forever.â€™ FU was reaching out to us, reminding us, even from beyond the grave. There are occasional moments when I wonder if all the joy might yet come crashing down, if the new will be less than the old. Take nothing for granted. But as one cynical friend mentioned the other day, for something that started as a joke, I should still be laughing. After all, he said, Iâ€™ve cashed another cheque. Well, he might say that. I couldnâ€™t possibly comment.
